top_comment.text:
Personally, the milgram experiment alone is enough to change my opinion on 
how well people actually act.

The argument that I'm going to get is "Well, back then there were no 
campaigns against killing people!" Recently, a television network recreated 
the experiment and got roughly the same results. How could we not have 
learned anything from all of the television and advertisement about how 
doing good things is generally good for you and others?

Some people, when told about the Milgram experiment, instantly think that 
they could never do that - people like me. Thinking about it more, I 
realized that I couldn't get a definitive answer unless I was put in the 
situation myself, after which point I thought that I would never be put in 
a situation like that. Leading me to my next point - the fact that people 
typically toss the idea that they'd every be put in that sort of situation. 
Instead of thinking about what they would do or say, past experiences kick 
in and nobody ever realizes that something like that could indeed happen to 
them.﻿

here, but such honesty about collectivism is of great interest to me; in

controllers. One day a Conservative might be in charge of speech.
       The problem with intervention by a central authority which has the 
sanction of force is that it is done in an environment where the actors are 
in other area still somewhat free. The minimum wage law for example -for it 
to work- requires employers not to fire anyone whose skill is insufficient 
for that wage. There must be created an agency to monitor that. The same or 
similar agency is necessary to make sure no employer who might have hired 
more at the lower wage, instead works harder those left behind because 
there are now more people competing for the same (now better paid) job. An 
agency must be able to regulate employer's decisions to invest in labor 
saving measures in case they choose the wrong reason: the cost of labor. 
And finally, to keep companies from going out of business, there must be an 
agency that subsidizes (and helps manage) those who just can't operate 
under those conditions.

comments.text:
That sounds rather Freudian of you; to posit ulterior motives for actions - 
implying the actualization or satisfaction of underlying or unconscious 
drives to be their source. However, it may be helpful to keep in mind two 
things as you decide:
1. It is not possible to ascertain knowledge of every case of every action 
- to say that every act is not selfless (or, charitably, not wholly 
selfless) can be considered a hasty generalization.
2. To discern between the propensity to commit acts embossed in kindness 
and gratuity from those in pretension is a scrupulous endeavor. I am not 
one to say if it may or may not be done - however, you may only actually be 
certain (to an extent) of the motives for your own actions. Attributing an 
associative, correlational, or causal relationship to every act is easy; 
whether it, in truth, is representative of that motivation is a speculative 
inference for all except the one who acts. (Some may even venture to say 
that, to an extent, this is not so.)
Whatever your decision may be, may it bring you peace.

comments.text:
Self verification - this is about subjective meaning and value and 
truthfulness, not objective truth. So, not falsifyiable in the way you 
mean, but better! Because you can actually know intimately your own 
beliefs, half-truths etc. better than any objective speculation :)
And it's not a position, it's a non-position, so not something you need to 
falsify anyway. The position above is that there are selfless and selfish 
acts, and that one is more valuable than the other. But if you get rid of 
the possibility of selflessness, then you only have 'selfish' acts that 
impact more or less people - that is, acts that benefit just you, acts that 
benefit you and another, acts that benefit you and a whole group of people 
etc.
So then the only distinction that really needs to be made is 
self-benefiting acts and self-destructive acts, where 'self' is used to 
encompass larger or smaller numbers.
Then things like wars can't be debated at the level of 'morality', but by 
how much they destroy the self, where self is the whole world. And 
individuals don't need to feel bad for really pursuing what they love to do 
'selfishly', because that will invariably positively involve and impact 
more and more people. 
I really don't think we need people running around 'saving' the less

comments.text:
+mrsblindhammer I am of the opinion that the "self" is not so cut and dry. 

Are you familiar with The Selfish Gene? Previously, evolutionary biologists 
saw genes simply as a means of self interested individual organisms to be 
fit, with genes that make the individual fitter being the ones most likely 
to persist. However Richard Dawkins proposes that genes don't necessarily 
persist because they help make the species fitter. Genes persist because 
they are simply good at persisting even at the expense of the fitness of 
the species. They are like parasites or freeloaders living off the altruism 
of other genes.

Individual organisms are still seen as self interested as always but now 
that selfishness is seen as a conglomerate of the selfishness of individual 
genes. The genetic "self" is a multitude in the same way a self interested 
social group of animals is made up of many self interested individuals. 
This obviously applies to human animals forming groups and acting like self 
interested wholes such as tribes, city-states, and nations.

Richard Dawkins explains this similarity between genetics and human society 
with the concept of memes. In the same way genes are units of information 
stored in DNA, memories/ideas, i.e. memes, are information stored in human 
minds. We are each of us a multitude, both genetically and 
psychologically/memetically. Humans are willing to jump on a grenade for 
the persistence of an idea for the same reason they are willing to jump on 
a grenade to save their own children.

In this way, altruism can be seen as selfish.
comments.author: SpazzyMcGee1337

comments.text:
+PSspecialist
I have come to believe that people that assert that "nobody is ever 
selfless" or that "altruism is insincere" are essentially taking their own 
subjective perspective and lazily applying it as a universal truth that 
describes all of humanity and everyone else. I don't mean or desire to come 
off as judgmental, but what often disgusts me is when someone brings up the 
whole "altruism is insincere," "no one can act without self-interest" (and 
mind that, being in quite a haste right now, I did not read this discussion 
thoroughly so I apologize if I missed some things) because at the end of 
the day, how can you tell *ME* why I choose to be compassionate and help 
others. How can you tell my friends or my loved ones, or yes that soldier 
that threw himself on top of a grenade, or that activist that risked 
assassination or execution by standing in front of a row of tanks or 
rallying the people to rise up against oppression, that the deepest roots 
of these actions are still selfish? Just because *you* *might* not be able 
to ever do an altruistic deed without it benefiting you in some way, even 
emotionally, doesn't mean that there aren't others out there, whose 
psychology you can never truly understand without being them, that are 
profoundly different from you, that feel things different from you. In 
other words, in my honest opinion, I can *presume* that those that believe 
that altruists are insincere or that no one can be compassionate without 
being self-serving to even the slightest degree, *probably* believe that 
because they themselves *lack empathy or compassion* and thus cannot 
understand that people certainly can do things for others at their own 
expense. They are applying their subjectivity universally, and that is 
irrational. It is *generalization* of all humanity.
And while you may argue that ultimately, the fulfillment of a desire (i.e. 
to help others) and the happiness or relief stemming from it supports this 
notion that no altruistic deed is without self-interest, I would argue that 
even if that can be said to be "self-interest," it is negligible or 
irrelevant when the overall consequences of an altruistic act is at the 
*expense* of the altruist. e.g. dying, or long-term suffering & sacrifice, 
where the altruist would be in far less pain, physically and 
psychologically, had (s)he chosen not to lend the aid (s)he did.

comments.text:
In high school, a girl in my school had cystic fibrosis and needed a lung 
transplant, but even with insurance, she couldn't afford the medical bills. 
So the school had fund raisers and a donation drive to help, where you 
could put your name on a banner if you donated. My classmate donated a 
quarter just to get his name on there, and I was disgusted. I then donated 
$40 to the cause and refused to put my name on the banner. My homeroom 
teacher happened to be walking by as I handed the cash to the office, and 
afterwards she asked, "Is she your friend?" I said no, that I had never met 
her and didn't know anything about her except that she needed the 
transplant. I had the money to help, so I wanted to. "But you didn't even 
put your name on the banner?" I said no again. She couldn't believe I had 
done that. When I got home and told my mom, she was actually angry that I 
had donated that much money. I told her, "I worked for it. I earned it. And 
I don't need it. She literally needs the money to live." She was still 
angry. I never regretted that decision, even 7 (maybe 8?) years later.

So, yeah. That's my most altruistic story. I would have many more, because 
I always try to help, but I haven't had much to offer people in a long 
time. I donated $50 to the ALS Ice Bucket challenge, though I shouldn't 
have because honestly, I could have used it and saved a bit. I try to 
donate here and there to various causes whenever I can (I especially like 
Stand Up 2 Cancer, because they're 100% nonprofit, so every cent you donate 
goes right to cancer research), but it's been virtually impossible for a 
while now. I set up a system for Tab For A Cause that, even with their 
rate-limiting, lets me donate about 500 units a day to the Foundation to 
Decrease Worldsuck (John and Hank's humanitarian charity)--I don't know 
what that translates to in dollar amounts, but it's something and it 
doesn't cost me anything at all, so I can afford to give it!

So I agree: ALTRUISM!
comments.author: IceMetalPunk

top_comment.text:
I personally disagree with the notion that everything we do is somehow 
motivated by our self interest. One of my most distinct memories from my 
early childhood was when I was at a wedding or reception, I was probably 5 
or 6 and they had given out balloons to the kids. I had gotten a balloon, 
and I noticed a girl who was probably a couple years younger than me, 
crying because she didn't get a balloon and there were no more. I liked my 
balloon, but I knew that my balloon would mean a lot more to this little 
girl, so I gave it to her. I didn't do it to feel good about myself, I 
didn't do it because someone would see me being kind, I did it because this 
girl was really upset about not having a balloon and I knew that she would 
enjoy it much more than I would. As soon as I gave it to her, some lady 
came up to me and told me that God had seen my act of kindness, and I 
remember being a little weirded out, but that's beside the point.
Although our altruistic actions often do have benefits for us, (feeling 
good about ourselves, recognition, etc.) I don't think it can be assumed 
that all good deeds are motivated by self interest and personal gain.﻿

comments.text:
+k3nny111

First off, homosexuality does not 'arise' due to genetics.

The only way for a dead gene to 'arise' is for there to be an outside 
factor to cause a direct mutation in the genetic code consistently and 
repeatedly.

This does not happen. Homosexuality is not genetic. It is a creation of the 
human mind separate from genetics itself.

The same is said for altruism.

There have been recorded instances all throughout history of people 
knowingly sacrificing their lives with the intention of giving their life 
in exchange for another's with there being no logical net gain to society.

The fact is, genetics does not explain altruism. The fact is, genetics does 
not explain homosexuality.

BOTH are results of some other factor.
comments.author: Belle La Victorie

comments.text:
+Belle La Victorie
"therefore do not carry the homosexual gene."

The current state of knowledge in behavioural genetics is that 
homosexuality arises, like many things, as an interconnected result of 
genes and environment.

If one of two monozygotic twins is homosexual, there is a higher than 
average chance of the other one being homosexual as well, even if they are 
separated at birth and grow up in completely different environments, hence 
there is a genetical component.

There are certain environmental factors as well, which push the chance up 
or down, which I can lay out if you like, but I don't want to write novel.

You can inherit the genetical combination that, given the right enviroment, 
trigger homosexuality from your parents. Note please that there is no 
single "homosexual gene", as far as we currently know.

So, in very short, it goes something like this. Your parents meet and have 
three kids. Both supply the genetical combinations which allow 
homosexuality to trigger, which are now present in all three kids. In two 
of them, it is phenotypical recessive and is not triggered, in one of them 
it is.

The two heterosexual ones go on and have babies. Since they have a sibling 
who is able to help them with their offspring, they tend to have more kids 
(the effect I already spoke about). Given the right partner, they pass on 
the genetical combination that allows for homosexuality.

That is why there is actually natural selection in favor of having a 
certain portion of the population being homosexual. 5 to 20%, as it turns 
out. 

My summary is very short and not very strictly defined, but this is 
factually the current state of knowledge in behavioural genetics. If you 
like to read about it in length, I can point you towards the relevant 
literature.

Now, back to altruism.

"The fact that people sacrifice their lives to protect others when there is 
a net loss to both the person and society factually exists."

Ok, first of all, sacrificing your life for anything is certainly no 
typical human behaviour. If it were, organ doner lists for example would 
become much shorter, as you could walk in a hospital right now and save 
probably around 4 people by giving up your organs. Are you willing to do 
that? I doubt it.

In many cases you only know a posteriori that the person actually just 
sacrificed its life, compared to just taking a big risk. A fireman for 
example can walk in a building and die trying to save an old woman, but did 
he sacrifice himself? Kinda, but not really, since he certainly expected to 
walk out again.

The "net loss" you'd experience when a young person "sacrifices" itself for 
an old person is also genetically irrelevant, because the broader 
behavioural construct that is partially selected for would be something 
like "x is willing to take big risks to save [others]"; there is certainly 
no "saving old ladies" gene.

So, to conclude, for the extreme rare cases of what you consider 
non-net-beneficial altruism, you can point towards behavioural patterns 
being applied which would normally be beneficial, but just in this case 
happen to be not. "Altruism" as such however still remains beneficial to 
the acting person, due to gratitude and effects on social standing, as long 
as the altruistic person isn't knowingly dying in the process, which would 
be a very very very rare case indeed.

You can see real altruism only when you squint your eyes. On close 
examination of ANY specific case, other mechanisms quickly explain away 
what seemed like altruism from a distance. 

The next question would be why I care that much about people being wrong on 
the internet.

While we are overwhelmed by the news media with the most horrendous 
disaster stories and most sensational crimes and atrocities, It is vital to 
realize that is NOT the picture of reality for the vast majority of the 
lives of the 7.3 billion people on our planet. 
The untold story is that the great majority of people out there are living 
normal caring lives, loving their neighbors, raising moral responsible 
children and do little things to make a better world EVERY DAY.  They 
volunteer, do favors for each other, give small gifts to brighten someone's 
day, they visit the sick in hospitals, they share food, they raise money 
for many good causes, they work together to find better ways to plan cities 
and respect the environment, and most importantly in the face of some of 
the hardships, they support, love and hug each other.   To keep a balanced 
view of what our world is like, I hope people take a few minutes every day 
to be thankful, and to remember there is much good that is happening out in 
the world as well.       peace

comments.text:
Actually, you nailed it. :)

In those experiments, what they found is people looked to others for cues, 
and were overestimating how good at reading themselves the others were. So, 
if "Bob" were in the room with "Jill" and "Todd", Bob would look over to 
Jill and Todd to see if they noticed anything. If neither of them seemed 
really aware of it, he would assume he might be wrong and go about his 
business. In the case with other real people. *sometimes* they caught on, 
but a lot of times they did not. However, with actors who are feigning 
complete ignorance, a person was much more likely to assume that they 
really were just imagining it, because the other two people seemed 
completely oblivious to it.
comments.author: Twosocks42

comments.author: Robert Blanchard

captions.text:
Let me tell you about Robber's Cave. In 1954,
a group of 11 boys, all about 12 years old,

were invited to a special summer camp in the
deep woods of southeastern Oklahoma, at a

place called Robber's Cave State Park. None
of the boys knew each other, although they

all came from similar backgrounds. They spent
their days bonding over things like games

and swimming and treasure hunts, and in no
time, they formed a tight friendly group.

They even came up with a name for themselves:
the Rattlers.

But soon they began to notice something. No,
not a guy in the woods with a hockey mask,

there was another group of boys also 11 of
them, also the same age, that had been staying

at the other end of the park the whole time.
The Rattlers never interacted with these other

boys, so they didn't know that those kids
were also spending time bonding over games

and swimming and treasure hunts, and that
they'd come up with a name for themselves,

too: the Eagles. But the Rattlers didn't like
the look of the Eagles, oh, no, they didn't

like them using their baseball diamond or
their dining hall.

And the feeling was mutual. It didn't take
long for each group to start complaining to

the camp's counselors about the other gang,
and eventually, they both said that they wanted

to set up a contest to determine once and
for all which group was better. The counselors

were only too happy to comply, because as
I'm sure you've figured out by now, those
counselors were actually researchers.

The man who set up what would be remembered
as the Robber's Cave Experiment was Turkish

American social psychologist Muzafer Sherif.
He was interested in what it would take for

rivals to overcome their differences and resolve
their conflicts. Specifically, Sherif wanted

to test something called Realistic Conflict
Theory. He hypothesized that conflict happens

when you combine negative prejudices with
competition over resources, and the boys at

Robber's Cave were well on their way to proving
him right.

Over the next couple of days, the Rattlers
and the Eagles competed against each other

for prizes in a series of games, like tug-of-war
and foot races, and soon, what started as

your basic trash talking and taunting and
name-calling morphed into fist-fights, thefts,

and raids on each others' cabins. But then
their dynamics changed or were changed for them.

After the games were over, the researchers
integrated the groups and gave the kids shared

goals that they could only achieve through
cooperation. The tide quickly turned. All

22 boys worked together to move a stalled
truck that was carrying their food, they took

care of a partially felled tree that was deemed
a danger to the camp, they collaborated in

setting up tents, even though they weren't
given complete sets of equipment. While isolation

and competition made enemies of the strangers, shared
goals and cooperation turned enemies into friends.

Over the past 39 weeks, we've learned a lot
about ourselves, our emotions and our personalities,

how our minds can get sick, how we can help
them get well again, why we can do vicious

things and then turn around and act like heroes.
So maybe it's fitting that we wrap up this

course by looking at a couple of opposing
forces that some consider the very definition

of human nature: aggression and altruism.
Conflict and cooperation. You might think

of it as the psychology of war and peace, or simply, 
what we can all learn from a bunch of 12 year olds.

In psychology, aggression is defined as "behavior
intended to hurt or destroy someone, something,

or even yourself." People aggress, as psychologists
say, in all kinds of ways, verbally, emotionally,

and physically, and for lots of different
reasons: out of anger, to assert dominance,

or as a response to fear. But that's just
a glimpse into why someone might become aggressive.
Where does the aggression actually come from?

Like a lot of behaviors we've talked about
it, it seems to emerge from that familiar

combination of biological factors, like genetic,
neurological, and biochemical influences,

and our environment and experience. In terms
of genetic influences, studies of twins, and

yes, Crash Course Psychology might have been
called Crash Course Studies of Twins, showed

that if one identical twin has a violent temper,
often the other one does, too, but fraternal
twins are much less likely to be so similar.

Neurologically speaking, no single area of
the brain controls aggression, but certain

areas like the limbic system do appear to
facilitate it. Research on violence and criminality

has also revealed a link between aggression
and diminished activity in the frontal lobes,
which play a vital role in impulse control.

And finally, our aggressiveness can be influenced
by our own biochemistry, hormones like testosterone

and glucocorticoids and pheromones have all
been implicated in animal models of aggression.

It's a little trickier in humans, it's a lot
trickier in humans, but it's highly likely

that our hormones are intimately linked with
feeling and showing aggression.

Obviously, aggression isn't just about biology.
Psychological and cultural factors also play

an important role, as does the power of the
situation. For example, there's the Frustration-Aggression

Hypothesis, the simple idea that people become
aggressive when they're blocked from reaching

a goal. To demonstrate, consider the not-very
aggressive sport of baseball. There's a study

that analyzed 44 years worth of baseball stats,
and focused on the more than 27,000 incidents

when a pitcher hit a batter with a ball. It
turned out that this was most likely to occur

if the pitcher was frustrated by a recent
home run or if one of his own teammates had
been hit by a pitch in the previous inning.

But we also learn aggression by watching others.
Like, if you grew up watching your parents

throw popcorn and jeering lewdly at their
most hated soccer team, you might have learned

something from their behavior. So combine
all of those biological factors and funnel

them through a particular person with a particular
history in a particular situation, and you

can begin to see how aggression can have many
roots that grow together.

Thankfully, though, humans are more than their
bad tempers. While some things in people will

leave us annoyed and angry, others breed friendship
and affection. So yes, there are positive

topics in social psychology, like altruism,
our selfless, even self-sacrificing regard

for the welfare of others. This could be something
as simple as jumpstarting a stranger's car

or as heroic as running into a burning building
to save someone. But if being altruistic is

so awesome, why aren't we all that way all
the time? Or maybe the better question is,

why do we ever do anything selfless, like,
what's in it for us?

In the late 1960s, social psychologists Bibb
Latane and John Darley conducted a series

of experiments examining when and why we help
others. In one experiment, they placed a subject

in a room, sometimes alone, sometimes with
two other subjects, and sometimes with two

actors posing as subjects. Then, they simulated
an emergency by filling the room with smoke

and waited to see if the subject would do
anything to alert the others or help themselves.

If the subject was alone, they'd report the
smoke 75% of the time. But subjects in a group

of three only spoke up 38% of the time. And
when they were stuck in the room with two

oblivious actors, only 10% of the participants
said anything to the others. Darley and Latane

found that people typically helped others
only if they noticed the incident, interpreted

it as an emergency, and then finally, assumed
responsibility, and all of these things were

much more likely to occur if a person was
alone, while the presence of others deterred
the person from helping.

This kind of diffusion of responsibility referred
to as the bystander effect, can weaken our

instinct for altruism. The bystander effect
is a bit like the concept of social loafing

that we talked about. If you're around other
people, it's easier to think that someone

else is going to pick up the slack or in this
case, come to the rescue.

When people do decide to help others, they
may do it for a number of reasons. One perspective

is that we tend to help others mainly out
of self-interest. By this thinking, helping

really isn't altruistic at all, and instead,
our actions boil down to a sort of cost-benefit

analysis. Like, maybe we'd turn in a lost
wallet because we're hoping for a reward or

we pitch in on a project at work because we
think we'll get recognized and promoted by

our bosses. Social psychologists contextualize
these kinds of examples in the broader theory

of social exchange. When it comes to doing
things for other people, we're always trying

to maximize our personal rewards while minimizing
our costs. But social exchange doesn't have

to be as selfish as that, it can also mean
that we act altruistically because we expect

that the people we help will go on to help
others, so if we give someone a hand changing

a tire, maybe they'll stop next time they
see someone else, maybe even us, broken down

on the side of the road. You might know this
concept, sometimes it's called the norm of

reciprocity, sometimes it's called paying
it forward.

And then there's the social responsibility
norm, which is the simple expectation that

people will help those who depend on them,
like any parent can expect to give more help

than they're going to receive from young children.
That's just part of being a parent. Naturally,

the world would be a delightful place if altruism
were the standard for human behavior, but
then, psychology wouldn't be nearly so interesting.

In some ways, you might say that what fuels
conflict is the opposite of altruism: self-interest.

Social psychologists view conflict as any
perceived incompatibility of actions, goals,

or ideas. That could mean two nations fighting
over a border, sparring religious or political

groups, or you and your boo fighting over
whose turn it is to do the dishes.

And in a weird conundrum of human behavior
a lot of conflicts arise from what psychologists

call "a social trap," where people act in
their own short term self-interest, even though

it takes a toll on the larger group and on
themselves over the long-term. You see this

kind of thing all the time on an individual
scale, like in a crime movie, when a criminal

just betrays all of his criminal friends to
get the big payout, it doesn't turn out very

well for him in the end. But on a larger scale,
you can find social traps taking their toll

on the environment, like when we poach elephants
to sell their ivory or cut down old growth

forests to make a quick buck in the lumber
market. Either way, when self-interest succeeds

in wrecking the collective interest by, say,
depleting some limited resource, it becomes

easy to start viewing our neighbors as competitors,
taking us right back to the ingroup vs. outgroup
mindset that we all know causes big problems.

So as long as there's self interest, there's
gonna be conflict.

But before you get all down on humanity, remember
those Robber's Cave boys. They were ready

to go full-on Lord of the Flies before shared
goals forced them to cooperate and ultimately,

make peace. The power of cooperation to make
friends of former enemies is one of the most

hopeful areas of psychological research. If
greed and self-interest can destroy the world,
perhaps cooperation can save it.

Today, you learned about the Robber's Cave
experiment and what it taught us about realistic

conflict theory and how shared goals can overcome
conflict. We looked at the physical and environmental

triggers of aggression, and the frustration-aggression
hypothesis. You also learned about altruism,

the bystander effect, and when we are more
or less likely to help a person in need, and

also about the social exchange theory, the
reciprocity norm, the social responsibility
norm, and social traps.

Thanks for watching, especially to all of
our Subbable subscribers who make Crash Course

possible. To find out how you can become a
supporter, just go to Subbable.com, and please

remember to go to YouTube.com/CrashCourse
and subscribe for more future Crash Courses
in the future.

This episode was written by Kathleen Yale,
edited by Blake de Pastino, and our consultant

is Dr. Ranjit Bhagwat. Our director and editor
is Nicholas Jenkins, the script supervisor

and sound designer is Michael Aranda, and
the graphics team is Thought Cafe.

title: Aggression V. Altruism: Crash Course Psychology #40
